newsitem.title: INDIA: Police seize rare skins worth $2.8 mln in Kashmir.
newsitem.headline: Police seize rare skins worth $2.8 mln in Kashmir.

text.p: Indian authorities in Kashmir have seized 15,000 rare animal skins worth at least 100 million rupees ($2.8 million), a police spokesman said on Saturday.
He said police on Friday raided houses in Baramullah town, 54 km (32 miles) north of Srinagar, and recovered the skins of wild cats, jackals, leopards and rabbits.
"The seizure includes skins of rare wildlife species. We have asked for the help of wildlife experts for the identification of these skins," the spokesman told Reuters.
"We have arrested six people who wanted to smuggle these skins out of India. The minimum value of these skins is 100 million rupees."
Police last month seized 800 skins worth some $200,000 in Srinagar, the summer capital of India's Himalayan state of Jammu and Kashmir.

Environmental activists say the government has neglected severe environmental degradation in the region, famous for its pristine lakes and houseboats, since 1990, when a separatist revolt erupted in the province. Police and hospitals say more than 20,000 people have died in insurgency-related violence.
